title: Abbreviated Syllabus
text:
Note: this is an abbreviated syllabus. The full syllabus is available through Classmate and/or Canvas.

Instructor Information

Dr.Â Samantha Seals
Office: 4/344



Meeting Times and Location

TR 11:00 am-1:40 pm

11:00 amâ€“12:15 pm: Lecture
12:30 pmâ€“1:15 pm: Daily practice
1:15 pmâ€“1:40 pm: Daily quiz

Physical classroom: 4/406
Zoom classroom: see Canvas or full syllabus for link



Office Hours

Monday: 2:00â€“4:00 pm (Central)
Wednesday: 2:00â€“4:00 pm (Central)
Other times by appointment



Grading and Evaluation
The course grade will be determined as follows:

Daily practice (25%): Each meeting day, students will complete an activity using Quarto and R. The resulting .html file should be submitted to the designated dropbox on Canvas by 11:59 pm on the specified date (see Canvas).
Daily quizzes (10%): Each meeting day, students will complete a timed quiz on Canvas. Time will be given during class for completion.
Assignments (40%): Every module will finish with an assignment to demonstrate the knowledge gained. These will be like the daily practice, but putting everything in the module together. The resulting .html file should be submitted to the designated dropbox on Canvas by 11:59 pm on the specified date (see Canvas).
Final Exam (25%): The final exam will be a timed concepts-based exam. While there may be some calculations needed, you will not be processing raw data. The final exam will be on Canvas on August 7, 2025. All students will have 3 hours to complete the exam.



Late Policy
Assigments have due dates, however, the dropboxes will not close until the end of the semester. All students are automatically granted â€œextensionsâ€ without question.
Note that if there is not a submission when I go to grade (after the initial deadline), I will assign a zero (0) and request that you submit the assignment when you are able to. This is only for record keeping purposes. There is no penalty for submitting late and a full grade will be given upon review of your submission.
Extensions are not available for daily practice, daily quizzes, or the final exam.

Conclusion and interpretation

There is (reject) or is not (ftr) sufficient evidence to suggest the alternative hypothesis in words.

title: STA4173 - Biostatistics - Summer 2025
text:
ğŸ“ Module 0: Review & R Foundations





In this introductory module, we will review essential concepts from STA2023 (Elements of Statistics) and get set up with the tools used throughout the course. Weâ€™ll cover:

Summary statistics and data visualizations.
Basics of statistical inference:

Confidence intervals for one mean,
Hypothesis testing for one mean.

Getting started with R, RStudio, and Quarto.

Basic R syntax: vectors & data frames/tibbles, functions, and the tidyverse.
Your first Quarto document.











ğŸŒ± Module 1: Exploring Continuous Outcomes in Two Groups





In this module, we explore methods for comparing continuous outcomes between two groups. Weâ€™ll cover:

Two-sample t-test for independent samples

Paired t-test for dependent samples

Assumptions on t-tests and how to assess
Wilcoxon rank-sum test

Wilcoxon signed-rank test










ğŸš Module 2: Exploring Continuous Outcomes in More Than Two Groups





In this module, we explore methods for comparing continuous outcomes between three or more groups. Weâ€™ll cover:

One-way ANOVA
Two-way ANOVA
Assumptions on ANOVA and how to assess
Posthoc testing (multiple comparisons)
Profile plots










ğŸ¬ Module 3: Exploring Regression Modeling





In this module, weâ€™ll explore describing the relationship between two continuous variables. Weâ€™ll cover:

Bivariate correlation

Pearsonâ€™s
Spearmanâ€™s

Simple linear regression
Multiple regression
Assumptions on regression and how to assess
Regression diagnostics










ğŸ¢ Module 4: Exploring Categorical Outcomes





In this module, we will begin exploring categorical outcomes. We will begin by reviewing analyses learned in STA2023 (Elements of Statistics):

One-sample proportions
Two-sample proportions

We will continue by expanding our knowledge:

\(\chi^2\) goodness-of-fit
\(\chi^2\) test for independence
Logistic regression

title: Looking for help?
text:
How do I typeset a hypothesis test?

Here is a basic template for typesetting hypothesis tests in Quarto: hyp_test_template.qmd
Remember to update subscripts when you are editing existing code.

Do you need help with your assignment?

Double check the slides for necessary code. Note that the headers of slides often match language used in the assignments.
Have you googled the error message you saw?
Have you asked your classmates (& Dr.Â Seals) on Discord? Truly, others have the same question, I promise! Do not be afraid to share a screenshot of your code and any corresponding output or error message.

Why did I lose points?

Please check the rubric; I try to give enough feedback for you to determine how to fix your assignment.
If clarification is still needed, please do not hesitate to come see me during office hours.

Is there tutoring?

No, there is no University-provided tutoring.
However, my research students are great resources. Please reach out to me if you are interested in hiring one of my students for tutoring.
